marriage_as_duty: Marriage must be pursued with propriety and intention.
A prudent match secures the peace of a household.
The honour of a union lies in its constancy.
To marry well is to fulfil one's obligation to society.
A suitable connection should not be delayed by affection alone.
Matrimony ought to be governed by reason and steadiness.
The prospect of alliance must consider family and estate.
Marriage, undertaken with care, ensures social harmony.
A timely engagement preserves respect and duty.
Choosing wisely reflects the decorum expected in society.
The obligation to unite advantageously is not easily set aside.
A proposal, made in earnest, requires thoughtful consent.
To delay marriage is to risk the loss of fortune and favour.
Courtship must yield to the demands of reputation.
Matrimony, when respectable, confirms the order of life.
romantic_love: True affection blooms without regard to fortune.
The heart may speak more sincerely than custom allows.
A look, exchanged in silence, may reveal all.
Love, once felt, cannot be easily forgotten.
No obstacle deters the warmth of true sentiment.
Affection grows where minds are equally met.
The feeling of attachment may defy all prudence.
Constancy of heart proves love's greatest virtue.
A union founded on esteem shall not falter.
The soul finds joy in mutual understanding.
Sincere love asks not for approval, only hope.
The softest word may kindle the deepest devotion.
Where affection resides, no riches are required.
The happiest match is made in genuine regard.
Love, once confessed, may alter the course of life.
social_class: Rank must be respected, even in the smallest acquaintance.
No person of breeding would act with such impropriety.
Connections of quality are seldom formed without consideration.
A distinguished name carries weight in every drawing room.
Manners reveal more of station than words ever can.
The difference in station was too great to be overlooked.
An invitation from such a house is never refused.
Those of fortune are expected to set an example.
It is not fit for one of lower standing to presume so much.
Deference is due to those of superior position.
A proper upbringing is the mark of good society.
The appearance of wealth often ensures favourable notice.
It is unwise to cross the bounds set by birth.
Esteem, once lost by vulgar behaviour, is seldom regained.
Politeness is the rightful currency of the higher circles.
moral_superiority: True virtue does not require display.
A calm conscience is the finest reward.
Integrity is often mistaken for pride.
The silent practice of goodness surpasses loud professions.
Conduct, more than words, reveals the character.
One must act rightly, though none should observe.
Modesty in virtue is its own strength.
Moral worth stands firm against ridicule.
The just mind seeks no applause.
Kindness, shown without motive, is most sincere.
Principle is rarely swayed by fashion.
A noble heart forgives where others resent.
The temptation to judge is resisted by the truly good.
Rectitude remains steady when popularity falters.
To do what is right, even when misunderstood, is a mark of honour.
stigma_of_spinsterhood: Long years without a match invite unwelcome speculation.
Absence from the altar is oft regarded with pity.
Solitude in age draws whispers from neighbours.
Unmarried life, though peaceful, is seldom esteemed.
A quiet household may be judged for its silence.
Propriety falters when society turns away its gaze.
Unclaimed affection becomes the subject of town remarks.
A life of books and walks is not always respected.
Invitations lessen when no engagement is declared.
The drawing room waits long for footsteps it may never know.
The unwed are expected to show gratitude for small kindnesses.
Even the virtuous are not spared from talk.
A settled routine is thought to hide regret.
The absence of union is read as failure, never as choice.
wealth_and_inheritance: A large fortune secures the respect of many.
Inheritance must descend with propriety and order.
A fine estate is the foundation of good standing.
Wealth, when wisely managed, brings lasting consequence.
The comfort of a household depends much upon income.
An heir must act with judgement and discretion.
Property ought to remain within the proper line.
The expectation of a legacy often governs behaviour.
A modest inheritance, though small, may still command esteem.
The loss of fortune alters one's place in society.
A will, fairly made, prevents much disagreement.
Possession of land confers both duty and honour.
The transfer of wealth should reflect long-held custom.
A good name and estate are seldom found apart.
Fortune must be regarded as both gift and charge.
female_professions: The governess arrived just before the afternoon tea.
A new companion was hired to attend the elder aunt.
The seamstress worked quietly by the drawing-room window.
A housekeeper must always ensure order in the household.
The maid prepared the hearth before breakfast.
The cook sent up a fine meal without delay.
A nurse was summoned from the nearby village.
The laundress was expected every Thursday morning.
A midwife had been recommended by the apothecary.
The nursery maid kept the child content through the storm.
A maid opened the door with great formality.
The scullery maid never missed her morning duties.
A milliner opened a small shop near the market square.
The dressmaker delivered the gowns in perfect condition.
A governess was observed walking alone on the lawn.
male_professions: The clergyman's position at the parish was newly vacated.
A commission in the navy had just been secured.
The solicitorâ€™s services were much in request throughout the county.
A living had been offered to the young curate.
The captain was received with great civility upon arrival.
A seat in Parliament was quietly being pursued.
The physician made daily calls upon the household.
A post in the East India Company was considered advantageous.
The steward managed the estate with unwavering diligence.
A new barrister was to be introduced at the assembly.
The architect surveyed the grounds with evident satisfaction.
The apothecary arrived in haste from the neighbouring town.
A tutor had been engaged to instruct the younger children.
The magistrate was often seen at the manor discussing affairs.
A commission in the militia was thought to be imminent.
reputation_and_gossip: The scandal was repeated in every drawing room.
A whisper of impropriety was heard in the village.
The rumour spread quickly through the county.
A tale of misconduct was told with great relish.
The story was embellished with each retelling.
A hint of scandal was enough to ruin a reputation.
The gossip was repeated with much satisfaction.
A tale of misfortune was recounted with great sympathy.
The news was received with much surprise and concern.
Reputation, once questioned, demands constant defence.
The rumour was dismissed with much laughter.
A tale of misbehaviour was told with great indignation.
The village had not ceased to speak of the matter.
The smallest impropriety grew into public scandal.
A name, once tarnished, is seldom restored.
truth_and_honesty: Truth was always preferred in moments of uncertainty.
The truth was revealed in the most unexpected manner.
The value of truth surpassed any gain from deception.
No comfort could arise from a false assurance.
A quiet admission was more respected than a bold lie.
Truth, though inconvenient, brought peace in the end.
To speak plainly was often the greatest courtesy.
An honest answer required more courage than wit.
The deception was uncovered with much surprise.
No ornament was needed where honesty resided.
A falsehood, once uttered, brought no rest.
The quiet resolve to speak the truth was never mistaken.
Trust was gained not by charm, but by constancy in truth.
vanity_and_appearance: A fondness for admiration often leads to folly.
There is no end to the trouble caused by excessive concern for dress.
An elegant figure is too often mistaken for virtue.
The mirror was consulted many times before the ball.
Appearances were studied with more care than character.
A new gown was ordered for the occasion.
The hair was arranged with great care.
Every glance sought confirmation of superiority.
The jewels were displayed with great pride.
The lace was admired by all who saw it.
A fan was used to hide a blush.
A taste for fine things was mistaken for refinement.
The hand was kissed with much ceremony.
Efforts to impress outweighed efforts to improve.
A gracious smile was practiced each morning.
matchmaking_positive: A sensible match is always worth the patience it requires.
A union was proposed with the greatest propriety.
The connection was spoken of as most suitable and promising.
All agreed that the understanding between them was natural.
A well-matched pair brings peace to both families.
The marriage was celebrated with the greatest decorum.
The proposal was met with quiet approval and gentle smiles.
It is not enough to admire; one must be compatible.
Every quality of character seemed to agree between them.
No interference could unsettle what was plainly right.
The match had been anticipated by all and surprised none.
There was harmony in manner, in taste, and in ambition.
A union built on esteem is rarely regretted.
Their acquaintance had ripened with remarkable ease.
The match was considered most advantageous by all.
matchmaking_negative: The union was much discussed, though seldom praised.
The match was thought to be most imprudent and hasty.
The match puzzled even those most acquainted with the pair.
Temperament and interest appeared quite at odds.
No amount of fortune could excuse the lack of harmony.
The engagement was accepted with resignation.
Conversation between them rarely found ease.
Their opinions clashed in every matter of consequence.
The arrangement seemed more of convenience than affection.
Each had been advised against it, but neither would yield.
The match was made in haste and repented steadily.
There was no laughter in their company, only obligation.
Affection was feigned, and respect was absent.
Those who knew them well predicted difficulty.
Their acquaintance had ripened with remarkable difficulty.
social_hierarchy: Respect is always due to those of higher station.
The distinction of rank was never more apparent.
Refinement of manner often denotes refinement of birth.
Connections in town are far superior to country acquaintance.
The disparity in fortune was too great to be ignored.
Invitations were extended only to those of respectable standing.
The title was borne with much dignity and pride.
Ancestry bore more weight than merit ever could.
Position must be preserved, even in the smallest matters.
The drawing room reflected distinction in every object.
The title was the mark of much distinction and honour.
Politeness was demanded, but only from those beneath.
The name was known for its long-held respectability.
A long-established estate lent dignity to every conversation.
The family was known for its long-standing influence.
